context: Time to call in Sherlock Holmes.
The droning was from Parliament.
I've seen a drone with a real honest-to-god flamethrower on it clearing power lines of debris. All you would have to do is bump the drones propeller to down it. What am I missing here?

replies.context: All you really need is a high power transmitter in the same band as the drones use (2.5 GHz?) and a highly directional antenna (shielded 20 element Yagi). This could be used to overload the drone's receiver's front end and cause the offender to lose control. Something like what I suggest would be no bigger than a small shoulder mounted rocket launcher.
What do you have against flamethrowers? Merry Christmas brother.
Used correctly by a competent person a flame thrower is a useful tool, but in this case it doesn't have the range required and has too much risk of collateral damage.

context:
I don't get why they could not stop it.
Radio Frequency and GPS jammers would cut the drones communications
Helicopters or other drones with nets to snag it
12  gauge shotgun with #10 shot would shred it without ground collateral damage
EMP device like RF Safe-Stop used on cars would scramble the drones electronics
Ram it with another drone
etc etc etc

The reason for such fear by authorities is that for under $25 you can build an EMP device that will destroy all electronics within a 1,000 foot radius. The EMP device can be mounted on a drone and used to disable the flight computers and control systems on the aircraft.

Once a drone with an EMP device downs a passenger plane then people the world over will come to realize just how dangerous air travel truly is in this modern age.

replies.context: Even 10,000 bucks would be considered cheap compared to the damage it could cause

replies.context: It’s actually very difficult.  The cheesy demo video is just a concept.  Nothing like that exists.  Dji has software that gives a backdoor to its drones, but it’s a 10,000 setup only sold to airports.  So, your wrong.

context: The real news is that the couple that were arrested were detained on suspicion and interrogated for 36 hours without an attorney present because the male had a model remote controlled helicopter and they lived near the airport.  They were later released because they both were nowhere near the airport when the "drone incursion" occurred.  No warrant.  No evidence.  Just a hunch gets you arrested.  I think they should sue for false arrest.

context:
We here in Israel have a missile defense system called Iron Dome, which can detect and acquire an incoming missile, calculate its projected trajectory and, within seconds, launch an anti missile missile to blow the hostile incoming rocket out of the sky, if the hostile rocket is destined to land in a populated area.
A little bit of software modification and the system should be able to handle drones.  
Buy an Iron Dome system from us for every airport and problem solved. 
Heck, haggle with us and you might even be able to buy 10 and get 1 free.
Small, agile, hard-to-spot (and also hard-to-hit) remotely controlled drones are the military revolution of the 21st century. This may be just the beginning.
It's actually easier to just print the news of when Government doesn't fail.

Of interest to me and not mentioned in the article is how the cops got hold of this couple in the first place,. I am assuming there are hundreds if not thousands of people living around the airport. Did the cops just blindly throw a stone and arrest the people in the house where the stone fell?

replies.context:
